expectations:
- MUST be in US English
      - Should break down each HTML element type into separate lessons
      - Should cover attributes, forms, multimedia, and accessibility as distinct concepts
      - Should not group multiple element types together (e.g., not "Lists and Tables" but separate lessons)
      
      
  - Each lesson should cover a SINGLE, SPECIFIC concept that can be explained within 10 short tweets
  - Break down topics into the smallest, most manageable units possible, so that each lesson can be learned in 2-3 minutes
  - If a topic is too broad, split it into multiple lessons
  - Each lesson should be extremely focused on a SINGLE concept
  - If a lesson is too broad, split it into multiple lessons
  - If you find yourself using "AND", "OR", or "VS" in a title, you should split it into separate lessons
  - Lesson titles should be short and specific to the exact concept covered
  - Build a logical progression from basic to advanced concepts
  - Ensure lessons build on knowledge from previous lessons
  - Focus lessons for this specific chapter, not the entire course
  - Don't include summary or review lessons. For example, do NOT create a lesson title "Summary of Key Concepts" or "Review of Chapter"
  - Don't include assessment or quiz lessons
  - Don't include final project or capstone lessons
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words (avoid "learn", "understand", "explore", "introduction to", etc.)
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the lesson content quality
  - Include an extensive list of lessons to cover all the concepts needed to learn the chapter. Complex topics will usually requiere more than 100 lessons
  
  Things to check:
  - Is each lesson too broad? If so, it should be broken down further
  - Can each concept be explained in 10 short tweets or less? If not, it should be broken down
  - Does each lesson focus on a single specific concept? If not, it should be split
  - Does it have lessons that don't belong in this chapter? If so, they should be removed

rankings.reasoning: Model B provides an excellent, comprehensive curriculum with 177 lessons that covers HTML elements individually and thoroughly. It properly separates concepts (e.g., separate lessons for each input type, individual ARIA attributes, accessibility patterns). The lessons progress logically from basics to advanced topics. Descriptions are concise and specific. It covers all required areas: attributes, forms, multimedia, and accessibility as distinct concepts. Each lesson is appropriately scoped for 10 tweets.

Model A offers 127 well-structured lessons with excellent granularity. It separates HTML elements appropriately (individual input types, semantic elements, ARIA attributes). Good coverage of accessibility, forms, multimedia. Descriptions are clear and concise. Logical progression from document structure through to accessibility. Some minor groupings exist (e.g., 'heading elements h1 to h6' as one lesson), but overall very strong.

Model F provides 193 lessons with strong coverage and granularity. It properly separates concepts and covers attributes, forms, multimedia, and accessibility well. Lessons are specific and focused. Good logical progression. Some lessons could be split further (e.g., 'The <sup> and <sub> Elements' grouped together violates the no-grouping rule), but overall excellent depth and organization.

Model C has 178 lessons with good coverage. It separates most elements appropriately and covers required topics. However, some lessons combine concepts (e.g., 'Description Lists dl' includes dt and dd implicitly, 'Headings h1–h6' grouped together). Some accessibility lessons are well done. Good progression but slightly less granular than top performers in certain areas.

Model E provides 224 lessons which is extensive, but some lessons are too broad or combine concepts (e.g., 'Headings: <h1> to <h6>' as one lesson, image format lessons could be consolidated). Good coverage of forms, multimedia, and accessibility. Some redundancy exists. Descriptions are generally clear but occasionally verbose. Solid overall but groupings detract from quality.

Model J has 145 lessons with reasonable coverage. It covers the main topics but groups some elements together (headings as one lesson, combines some concepts). Accessibility coverage is present but lighter than top models. Form elements are reasonably separated. Some lessons are slightly too broad ('Heading Elements' for all six levels). Descriptions are clear.

Model I provides only 79 lessons which is notably insufficient for comprehensive HTML coverage. While the lessons it includes are focused and well-described, major gaps exist - missing many input types, limited accessibility coverage, insufficient form validation attributes. Good quality for what's included but lacks the 'extensive list' required by the task.

Model G has 87 lessons which is quite limited. Many topics are grouped together (e.g., 'Headings' as one lesson, 'Lists: Unordered/Ordered' could be more granular). Coverage of accessibility is minimal (only 6 lessons). Forms coverage is basic. Multimedia coverage is adequate but not comprehensive. Missing many specific concepts.

Model H provides 82 lessons which is insufficient. Groups concepts together ('Heading Elements' for all levels, combined accessibility coverage). Limited form input type coverage, minimal ARIA attributes. Meta viewport covered but missing many nuanced HTML concepts. Accessibility section is underdeveloped. Some lessons are too broad.

Model D has only 55 lessons which is far too few for comprehensive HTML coverage. Major gaps in content - only one combined lesson on 'ARIA Roles', missing most form input types, no srcset/picture elements, minimal accessibility coverage. Groups headings, skips many elements entirely. Does not meet the requirement for an 'extensive list' of 100+ lessons.

Model K has 88 lessons which is insufficient for the topic. Separates h1-h6 which is good, but groups other concepts. Has separate heading elements but limited accessibility coverage. Forms are reasonably covered but missing validation attributes. Multimedia coverage is basic. Missing many HTML5 elements and advanced concepts.

This model provides the most comprehensive and well-structured list of lessons (146 total). It excels in granularity, breaking down complex topics like forms and accessibility into distinct, manageable concepts (e.g., separating 'The label element', 'Labeling with for', and 'Implicit Labels'). It strictly adheres to all negative constraints, avoiding 'AND'/'VS' groupings in titles. Its progression is logical and the descriptions are precise.

Model E is an extremely close second with 142 lessons. It demonstrates excellent granularity, particularly in the forms section where it breaks down every input type and button type into separate lessons. It adheres perfectly to the title constraints (e.g., separating 'Image Width' and 'Image Height'). It is slightly less detailed in the accessibility breakdown compared to Model B but is otherwise exceptional.

Model C offers a high-quality list (127 lessons) with a strong focus on best practices (e.g., 'Placeholder Is Not a Label'). It adheres well to formatting constraints. It is ranked below B and E simply because it has slightly fewer lessons covering the minute details of attributes and input types, but it remains a superior output.

Model A provides a solid list of 108 lessons with good coverage of metadata and head elements. However, it violates the negative constraint regarding lesson titles by using 'AND' to group concepts several times (e.g., 'link rel preconnect and preload', 'input type date and time'). Ideally, these should be split.

Model I offers a clean list of 101 lessons. It is well-structured and mostly adheres to constraints, with only a minor violation ('width and height Attributes'). It is slightly less comprehensive than Model A in terms of metadata and advanced attributes but follows the splitting rules better than models ranked lower.

Model J provides 114 lessons, showing good depth. However, it groups fundamental concepts that should be split, such as 'Opening and Closing Tags' and 'Image Width and Height', violating the specific negative constraints provided in the prompt.

Model F has excellent content depth (137 lessons) comparable to the top models. However, it repeatedly violates the explicit instruction to avoid using 'VS' in titles (e.g., 'Block-Level vs Inline Flow', 'Absolute vs Relative URLs'). These concepts were successfully split by higher-ranked models, leading to a significant penalty for instruction adherence despite the high content quality.

Model G provides 94 lessons. It is a decent list but lacks the granular depth of the higher-ranked models. It groups some attributes (e.g., 'Image Width and Height') and covers fewer specific input types and accessibility features.
Model H provides 93 lessons. It covers the basics but misses many HTML5 specific input types and advanced features. It also contains grouping violations in titles (e.g., 'Image Width and Height').
Model K provides only 84 lessons. It lacks sufficient detail and granularity for a complex chapter, grouping many concepts that should be expanded upon.

Model D provided the fewest lessons (62), failing to meet the requirement for an 'extensive list'. The lessons are too broad (e.g., 'Web Accessibility' as a single lesson) and do not provide the granular breakdown requested.

Most complete and well-structured progression from document fundamentals to semantics, text, lists, links, images, tables, forms, multimedia, then accessibility. Lessons are generally single-concept with concise, US-English descriptions. Strong coverage of attributes (global + many form-specific), forms (including submission mechanics), multimedia, and accessibility as distinct areas. Minor issues: a few titles are slightly broad (e.g., “Autoplay Restrictions”, “Accessible Names”), and the total count is still far under the “>100 lessons usually” expectation for a complex chapter.

Very strong granularity and separation of concerns (lots of element-by-element lessons plus attribute-by-attribute). Covers forms, multimedia, and accessibility distinctly and with good technical accuracy. However, it has several titles that violate the “no AND/OR/VS” guidance (e.g., “link rel preconnect and preload”, “autoplay and muted attributes”, “semantic versus non-semantic elements”), and a couple lessons bundle multiple items (e.g., “heading elements h1 to h6”, “thead tbody tfoot”). Also ends with a somewhat odd/overreaching accessibility item (“color contrast considerations in HTML”).

Broad coverage across elements, attributes, forms, multimedia, and accessibility, with many lessons broken into manageable units and mostly clear US English. Still includes multiple “X vs Y” or combined concepts in titles (e.g., “Block-Level vs Inline Flow”, “Absolute vs Relative URLs in href”, “Defer and Async Script Attributes”, “The <sup> and <sub> Elements”), which conflicts with the strict ‘single concept’ rule. Also includes some scope creep/generalities (e.g., “Progressive Enhancement with HTML”, “HTML5 Semantic Elements Overview”).

Good breadth and mostly atomic lessons; includes modern elements (details/summary/dialog/template) and many form and accessibility microtopics. Some lessons are still too bundled (“Headings h1–h6”, “Landmark Elements for Navigation”), and a few items feel outside a tight ‘HTML elements chapter’ scope or are very advanced/new (popover/popovertarget) without groundwork. Overall less consistent adherence to the ‘single specific concept’ constraint than A/B.

Large list with decent separation for many elements and attributes, and includes forms/multimedia/accessibility sections. But it violates the chapter-focus constraint more often (e.g., “Open Graph Meta Tags”, “HTML Validation”, “Common HTML Errors”, “Favicon Setup”), contains some fluffier/intro phrasing (“Why Semantic HTML Matters”), and several lessons remain broader than the 10-tweet constraint. Still reasonably usable as a curriculum outline.

Fairly comprehensive and clear, with many element-by-element lessons and decent accessibility coverage. However, it contains repeated/duplicated concepts (meta covered twice in different places, title/lang repeated), some bundled topics (“The Document Structure” mixes doctype concept with structure), and a lot of lessons are more like a general HTML chapter than a tightly scoped, highly granular micro-lesson set. Also still well under the ‘extensive >100’ expectation.

Covers many core elements and some attributes/forms/multimedia, but the set is less granular and less complete than stronger outputs (missing many key attribute lessons, fewer accessibility-specific lessons, limited table/form depth compared to A/B). Some descriptions have awkward wording (“Containers user input fields…”, “Containers bullet-point list items…”), and there’s occasional imprecision (e.g., mentioning obsolete ‘manifest’ attribute on html).

Mostly correct and readable, but coverage is clearly incomplete (no dedicated accessibility section beyond scattered lang/alt mentions; very limited multimedia; few attribute lessons). Many lessons are still somewhat generic and the curriculum is not extensive enough for the stated requirement. Overall closer to a short chapter outline than the requested large micro-lesson list.

Has the basics across structure/text/links/images/lists/forms/tables/media plus a small accessibility tail, but many titles violate the ‘no grouping’ guidance (e.g., “Lists: Description Lists” bundles dl/dt/dd; “Global Attributes” is broad; “Keyboard Navigation Basics” is broad). Coverage depth is shallow (few attributes, minimal accessibility), and the lesson set is not extensive.

Significant rule violations: multiple element types grouped into umbrella lessons (“Text Elements”, “Semantic Elements”), headings split into h1/h2/etc. but also grouped earlier; accessibility is a small afterthought; form/multimedia lessons are sparse and sometimes inaccurate (e.g., track described as “Fallback content for unsupported multimedia”). Overall not sufficiently granular, not extensive, and contains content-quality errors.

Too short and too high-level for the requirements, with many grouped/broad lessons (e.g., “Subheadings h2 through h6”, generic “Web Accessibility”, generic “Hyperlinks”). Missing many required distinct concept areas in depth (attributes breadth, multimedia attributes, accessibility patterns, table/form details). Also uses the outdated term “Self-Closing Elements” in a way that can be misleading in HTML (void elements). Lowest adherence overall.
